[[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1984|09|13|1933|05|01|mf=y}}
Atlanta, Georgia, United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[East Coast blues]], [[jump blues]], [[soul blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1950–1969 | label = Various, including [[Okeh Records|Okeh]], [[Jamie Records|Jamie]], [[King Records (USA)|King]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Titus Turner''' (May 1, 1933 – September 13, 1984) was an [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and [[East Coast blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/titus-turner-mn0000931567/biography |title=Titus Turner | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} His best remembered [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were "We Told You Not To Marry" and "Sound-Off," plus he wrote "[[Leave My Kitten Alone]]," and "[[Tell Me Why (1956 song)|Tell Me Why]]."{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html |title=The 1980s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==Biography== Born in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], Turner's debut [[single (music)|single]] release in 1950 was "Where Are You" on [[Aladdin Records (US)|Aladdin Records]], billed as Mr. T and his Band. In 1951 his follow-up "Stop Trying to Make a Fool Of Me" appeared on [[Regal Records (1949)|Regal Records]].{{cite web|url=http://koti.mbnet.fi/wdd/titusturner.htm |title=WangDangDula.com |publisher=Koti.mbnet.fi |date=2011-03-13 |accessdate=2014-01-31}} He followed this a year later on [[Okeh Records|Okeh]], issuing eight tracks including "Got So Much Trouble." He had a spell with [[Mercury Records]]'s imprint, Wing, but was not commercially successful until 1955, when [[Little Willie John]] recorded Turner's "All Around the World". The track, re-titled "Grits Ain't Groceries," was [[cover version|covered]] by [[Little Milton]]. Turner and John then co-wrote "[[Leave My Kitten Alone]]", later covered by [[Johnny Preston]], [[The Beatles]] and [[Elvis Costello]]. In 1959 the [[King Records (USA)|King]] [[record label|label]] issued Turner's first [[hit single]], "The Return of Stagolee," an [[answer song]] to [[Lloyd Price]]'s "[[Stagger Lee (song)|Stagger Lee]]". He repeated the trick with his next release, "We Told You Not To Marry," an antidote to Price's "[[I'm Gonna Get Married]]." In 1960, [[Ray Charles]] recorded the Turner song, "Sticks and Stones", which has also seen many cover versions over the years. By 1961 Turner had his biggest solo success with "Sound-Off," which came from the only [[album]] he ever released. The track was described by [[Joel Whitburn]] in ''Top Pop Singles 1955-2002'' as a "popular [[United States Army|US Army]] [[Military cadence|marching drill chant]]," which was originally a no. 3 hit for [[Vaughn Monroe]] in 1951. Later singles failed to find a market, and Turner recorded for a plethora of labels throughout the 1960s without further tangible success. These included "Eye to Eye" (Okeh, 1966).{{cite web|url=http://www.georgwa.demon.co.uk/okeh_singles.htm |title=Okeh Singles Listing From 1963-1970 |publisher=Georgwa.demon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} In 1969 his self-penned track "His Funeral, My Trial" was his final release. Turner died in Atlanta in 1984. ==Notable songwriting credits== *"All Around the World" - also known as "Grits Ain't Groceries" (Turner) *"Big John" (Turner) *"Get on the Right Track Baby" (Turner) *"Hey Doll Baby" ([[Traditional music|Traditional]]/Turner) *"Hold Your Loving" (Bernice Snelson, Turner) *"If It's Good" ([[Julia Lee (musician)|Julia Lee]]/Turner) *"[[Leave My Kitten Alone]]" ([[Little Willie John]]/James McDougal/Turner) *"Little Girl Lost" ([[Luther Dixon]]/[[Lou Harrison]]/Turner) *"Living in Misery" (Turner) *"Lotus Blossom" ([[Julia Lee (musician)|Julia Lee]]/Turner) *"People Sure Act Funny" ([[Bobby Robinson (record producer)|Bobby Robinson]]/Turner) *"Soulville" ([[Henry Glover]]/[[Morris Levy]]/[[Dinah Washington]]/Turner) *"[[Sticks and Stones (Titus Turner song)|Sticks and Stones]]" (Turner) *"Stop The Pain" (Turner) *"Tell It Like It Is" (Turner) *"[[Tell Me Why (1956 song)|Tell Me Why]]" (Turner){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/titus-turner-mn0000931567/songs |title=Titus Turner | Songs |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Sound Off'' (1961) - [[Jamie Records|Jamie]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/titus-turner-mn0000931567/discography/all |title=Titus Turner | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ===Compilation albums=== *''Soulville: Golden Classics'' (1990) - Collectables Records *''Sound Off: The Jamie Masters'' (1994) - Bear Family *''Titans of R&B'' (1998) - Red Lightnin' ([[United Kingdom|UK]]) *''1949-1954'' (2005) - Classics R&B ===Chart singles=== *"Return of Stagolee" ([[King Records (USA)|King 5186]]) (April 1959) - [[United States|US]] [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] no. 29 *"We Told You Not To Marry" (Glover 201) (December 1959) - US [[Billboard Hot 100|Pop]] no. 83 *"Sound-Off" ([[Jamie Records|Jamie 1174]]) (March 1961) - US Pop no. 77{{cite book | first=Joel | last= Whitburn | year= | title= Top Pop Singles 1955-2002 | edition= | publisher= Billboard | location= | isbn= 0-89820-155-1 | page= }} ==See also== *[[List of East Coast blues musicians]] *[[List of jump blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.soulfulkindamusic.net/tturner.htm Comprehensive singles discography at Soulfulkindamusic.net] {{Authority control|VIAF=7654076}} {{Persondata | NAME = Turner, Titus | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and [[East Coast blues]] singer and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH = May 1, 1933 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = September 13, 1984 | PLACE OF DEATH = Atlanta, Georgia, United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turner, Titus}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues musicians]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:East Coast blues musicians]] [[Category:Jump blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Atlanta, Georgia]] [[Category:Writers from Atlanta, Georgia]]
